docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the past five springs, a pair of Baltimore Orioles has returned to our yard to nest. This year I was worried. The last I had seen of the dazzling orange patriarch, he was bravely, desperately leading a screeching redtail hawk away from his brood. Then they all vanished. Thus when Daddy-O returned this spring, I rejoiced -- and followed the flash of wings to the hammocklike nest swinging high in our maple tree. The fledging of the ensuing baby orioles took place at a tender time in our human nest; our 16-year-old son, Sam, had gotten his driver's permit. It was a milestone I've dreaded since he began taking solid food. So it was only natural that I would do the sappy Mom thing and anthropomorphize the avian drama. I envied Mama Oriole her apparent sangfroid as the baby birds plunged, flapping, into the void. The female chick was cautious, taking short test flights to nearby branches. Her two snazzy brothers favored the kamikaze approach; death-defying free falls landed them, tweeting and flailing, in the trumpet vine. Every time they made it back to the nest, a squawky fracas ensued that sounded to my fretful maternal ears like a warbled equivalent of ''What were you thinking?''

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Wharton Club of New York revived its Joseph Wharton Awards after a 15-year hiatus, it gave one of the honors to a rug merchant. Not just any rug merchant, of course, but Connie K. Duckworth, a retired managing director of Goldman Sachs, for her work as founder of Arzu, a nonprofit group that employs Afghan women as carpet weavers and provides education and health care for their families. Ms. Duckworth said her Wharton training ''helps me bring private-sector skills to apply to public-sector problems.'' Arzu has sold 350 rugs to buyers like Laura Bush and Nicky Hilton; Ms. Duckworth said it would soon sell 1,000 annually.
docs.abstract: Wharton Club of New York awards its Joseph Whart Award to Connie K Duckworth, retired managing director of Goldman Sachs, for hear work as founder of Arzu, nonprofit group that employs Afghan women as carpet weavers and provides education and health care for their families Arzu has sold 350 rugs to buyers like Laura Bush and Nicky Hilton (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: EACH year, more than 140,000 New Yorkers are injured on the job. For most, the main source for paying medical expenses and replacing lost wages is the workers' compensation system. As a lawyer whose career is devoted to representing these injured workers, I have spoken to thousands of people over the years about their individual cases and about the limitations of the system. I've spent many unhappy hours explaining that even though someone may not be able to pay rent or feed his family on his benefit amount, he is getting the most the law allows. Often, I have had to tell clients that they cannot have necessary medical testing or treatment until they get approval from their insurance company. And recently, I have had to explain to workers with problems related to 9/11 that they've missed the deadline for claims because of technicalities in the Workers' Compensation Law.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by lawyer Robert Grey holds that because New York Compensation Insurance Rating Board is governed by the insurers themselves, it is impossible to know if employers are being overcharged for workers compensation coverage; calls on state Legislature to empower Insurance Department to audit insurers and publish results (M)
